definition: to push up one's sleeves/to reject or resist/to seize/to perturb/to steal
non-Han people, esp. to the East of China/barbarians/to wipe out/to exterminate/to tear down/to raze

lit. rich country, strong army (idiom); slogan of legalist philosophers in pre-Han times/Make the country wealthy and the military powerful, slogan of modernizers in Qing China and Meiji Japan (Japanese pronunciation: Fukoku kyōhei)
(orig.) tents forming the offices of a commanding officer/administration of a military government/(medieval Japan) "bakufu", administration of the shogun
to recover one's power or authority/restoration (of a past regime)
TOYOTOMI Hideyoshi (1536-1598), Japanese warlord, undisputed ruler of Japan 1590-1598
the Warring States period (475-221 BC)/Japanese Warring States period (15th-17th century)
expel the Manchu, revolutionary slogan from around 1900
to burn the Confucian classics and bury alive the Confucian scholars (acts supposedly committed by the first emperor 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2])
to save from extinction/to save the nation
bushidō or way of the warrior, samurai code of chivalry
non-Han tribes in the east and north of ancient China/barbarians
Prince Shōtoku Taiji (574-621), major Japanese statesman and reformer of the Asuka period 飛鳥時代|飞鸟时代[Fei1 niao3 Shi2 dai4], proponent of state Buddhism, portrayed as Buddhist saint
